children.name: to make sb feel unsure about sth
make sb unsure
children.definition: /uncertai
examples: make sb unsure/uncertain about
▪ The news about the bomb made me uncertain about travelling to the area.
make sb unsure/uncertain of
▪ Her previous experiences made her very unsure of the wisdom of marrying again.

children.name: raise doubts
children.definition: to make people become unsure about sth they were previously fairly sure about:làm dấy lên sự hoài nghi
examples: I don’t want to raise too many doubts, but I wonder whether he’s really fit for the job.
raise doubts about/over
Her report has raised doubts about the likely success of this project.
raise doubts in sb’s mind
The new evidence raised doubts in the minds of jury members.

children.name: it makes you wonder
children.definition: especially spoken use this to say that something makes you unsure about a previous belief:làm ai đó tự hỏi
examples: They obviously know each other. It makes you wonder.
it makes you wonder if/whether etc
So many people believe in astrology, it makes you wonder if it’s all true.
His behaviour after hearing my news made me wonder if he knew more than he had told me.

children.name: to make sb sure about sth
convince
children.definition: to make sb sure about sth, especially when this is difficult to do: “thuyết phục”
examples: Our new policy on tax reform will certainly help the economy. The only problem will be convincing the voters.
convince sb (that)
The discovery of a body finally convinced Mrs Hayes that her son was dead.
I had tried to convince my company’s president that these ideas were viable.
convince sb of sth
How many more deaths will it take to convince the authorities of the need to test drugs more thoroughly?

children.name: when you feel sure about sth
sure
children.definition: /ʃʊəʳ/  if you are sure about something, you believe that it is definitely true or correct:chắc chắn
examples: ▪ ‘The car was a BMW’ ‘Are you sure?’
sure (that): chắc chắn rằng
▪ I’m surprised she isn’t here - I was sure she would come.
▪ Are you quite sure that he understood your instructions?
sure about: chắc chắn về
▪ I think children are influenced by these films, but it’s impossible to be sure about this.
sure of: chắc chắn về điều gì
▪ You need to be sure of your facts before making any accusations.
pretty sure: khá là chắc
▪ I’m pretty sure Barbara still works here.
absolutely sure: hoàn toàn chắc
▪ We do not believe this is the body of the missing girl, but we have to check to be absolutely sure.

children.name: convinced
children.definition: sure that sth is true, even when you cannot prove it:tin chắc
examples: convinced (that)
We’ve had no news of him, but we’re convinced he’s still alive.
She became convinced that her boyfriend was seeing someone else.
convinced of
Brown’s wife was convinced of his innocence.

children.name: no doubt
children.definition: have /hæv ˌnəʊ ˈdaʊt/  to be so certain about something that there are no doubts in your mind:không nghi ngờ gì
examples: have no doubt (that)
▪ I’ve no doubt that his story is true.
have no doubt about/of
▪ My boss told me he had no doubt about my abilities as a salesman.

children.name: certain
children.definition: /ˈsɜːʳtn/  completely sure that something is true:chắc chắn
examples: certain (that)
▪ Are you certain you didn’t leave your keys at home?
certain about: chắc chắn về
▪ He was certain about one thing - she would come back one day.
certain of: chắc chắn về điều gì
▪ She won’t let you borrow the car - I’m certain of that.
absolutely certain: hoàn toàn chắc chắn
▪ Don’t stop looking until you’re absolutely certain you’ve found the place you want.

children.name: know
children.definition: /nəʊ/  to have a strong feeling that something is right or true, although there may be nothing to prove:chắc
examples: know (that): chắc rằng
▪ Sally knew that she and Carl would be the best of friends.
▪ I just know your mother will love this necklace.
▪ As soon as the phone rang, we knew something terrible must have happened.
know it: chắc chắn
▪ She’s going to pass -- I just know it!

children.name: satisfied
children.definition: /ˈsætɪsfaɪd, ˈsætəsfaɪd/  sure that you know the truth about something that has happened, because you have enough information:chắc chắn
examples: satisfied (that)
Police are now satisfied that her death was an accident.

children.name: confident
children.definition: /ˈkɒnfɪdənt, ˈkɒnfədəntǁˈkɑːn-/  sure that something good will happen, or that you will be able to achieve what you want:tự tin
examples: ▪ ‘Do you think you’ll win tomorrow’s game?’ - ‘Well, we’re all feeling pretty confident’.
confident (that)tự tin rằng
▪ Doctors are confident that he’ll make a full recovery.
confident of:tự tin về điều gì
▪ A spokesman said the government was confident of winning the vote and would not discuss the possibility of defeat.

children.name: I bet
children.definition: /aɪ ˈbet/ spoken informal say this when you feel sure that something is true:toán đoán là vậy
examples: I bet (that) tôi đoán rằng
▪ I bet you’re tired after such a long journey.
▪ I bet she hasn’t told her parents about this.

children.name: must
children.definition: /məst, strong mʌst/  especially spoken if you say that something must be true or must have happened, you are sure about it, because of information you have or things you have noticed that make it seem very likely:hẳn là
examples: ▪ You must remember Sally Newton. She was in our French class.
must have: hẳn là đã
▪ Kim didn’t answer when I called - she must have gone to bed.
▪ She didn’t get into movies just because her mother was a famous actress, but it must have helped.

children.name: can’t
children.definition: /kɑːntǁkænt/  especially spoken if you say that something can’t be true or can’t have happened, you are sure that it is not true or has not happened:không thể
examples: ▪ He says he’s 21 but he can’t be older than 18.
can’t have: không thể đã
▪ She can’t have gone to bed yet - it’s only 8 o'clock.
▪ If you failed that exam you can’t have worked very hard.

children.name: I’d put money on it
children.definition: /aɪd pʊt ˈmʌni ɒn ɪt/ you say I’d put money on it when you are so sure of something that you would be willing to take the chance of losing money if you were wrong:tôi chắc chắn về điều đó
examples: ▪ ‘Do you really think the president will win again?’ ‘I’d put money on it.’

children.name: positive
children.definition: especiallyspokencompletely sure that sth is true - use this especially when other people are saying it might not be true:chắc chắc, “tích cực”
examples: ‘Are you sure you locked the door?’ ‘Yes, I’m positive
I’m absolutely positive I haven’t made a mistake.
"Are you sure it's okay for me to use your mother's car?" "Positive."
positive that
Are you positive(that)you saw me switch the iron off?
positive about
"It was him - I saw him take it." "Are you positiveaboutthat?"

children.name: certain
children.definition: /ˈsɜːʳtn/  hiển nhiên, chắc chắn
examples: ▪ Computer prices will continue to fall - that’s certain.
it is certain (that)
▪ Nobody knows exactly who built the manor, but it is certain that an architect called John Sturges supplied the drawings.
almost certain
▪ As the results came in, it was now almost certain that Ken Livingstone would be the new Mayor of London.
certain death/failure/disaster etc
▪ Ignoring all warnings, the general led his men to certain death.i

children.name: definite
children.definition: /ˈdefɪnɪt, ˈdefɪnət, ˈdefənt/  if something is definite, it is certain because someone has officially stated that it will happen, is true etc:chắc chắn
examples: ▪ I’ve got a good chance of getting the job, but it’s not definite yet.
▪ We have some statistics, but we really need something more definite before we can make any firm decisions.
definite answer
▪ I don’t know what time she’s coming. She won’t give me a definite answer.

children.name: conclusive
children.definition: /kənˈkluːsɪv/  conclusive proof/evidence/argument etc proof etc that is certainly true and cannot be doubted:thuyết phục, xác định
examples: ▪ We still have no conclusive proof that Walters was at the scene of the crime.Chúng ta có bằng chứng xác định rằng Walters đã dàn cảnh tội phạm
▪ They have been able to collect some data, but as yet nothing really conclusive.Họ đã có ý tưởng thu thập dữ liệu, nhưng vẫn chưa có gì để kết luận
conclusively [adverb] một cách quả quyết

▪ The documents show conclusively that Pickering was aware of, and took part in, corrupt deals.Những tài liệu đưa ra một cách quả quyết rằng Pickering đã để tâm, và tham gia vào những giao kèo tham nhũng

children.name: to make certain that sth will happen
make sure
children.definition: /make certain Make sure is more common in spoken English than make certain: chắc chắn rằng
examples: ▪ I think Harry knows the way, but I’ll go with him just to make sure.
make sure/make certain (that)
▪ Make sure you lock your car.
▪ You must make sure that your dog is vaccinated against illness.
▪ The producer must make certain there is enough material to fill the one-hour programme.

children.name: ensure
children.definition: insure/alsoensureUK /ɪnˈʃʊəʳ/  to do something in order to be certain that something will happen in the way you want it to: đảm bảo
examples: ▪ To insure accuracy, three consultants worked closely with the producer during filming.
insure/ensure that
▪ It is important to insure that universities have enough funds to carry out important research.
▪ A new television campaign has been launched to ensure that the victims are not forgotten.

children.name: see that U
children.definition: see that/see to it that especially spoken to make sure that sth sb has asked you to do is done: hãy chắc rằng, đảm bảo rằng
examples: ▪ I’ll see that Jason isn’t late for school again!
▪ Will you please see to it that this work is finished by the end of the week.
see to it
▪ ‘This letter must be posted today.’ ‘Don’t worry, I’ll see to it.’"

children.name: know for certain
children.definition: know/say for certain
examples: to know or sostatemething without doubt
_I don't know for certain if she's coming.
_I can't say for certain how long I'll be there.

children.name: assure
children.definition: verbMAKE CERTAIN
examples: to cause something to be certain
_The play's popularity has been assured by the critics' rave reviews.

children.name: concrete
children.definition: adjective
examples: clear and certain, or real and existing in a form that can be seen or felt
_They think she killed her husband, but they've no concreteevidence.
_We've got a general idea of what wewant, but nothing concrete at the moment.

children.name: conclusively
children.definition: adverb
examples: without any doubt
_It is impossible todemonstrate/proveconclusively that the factory is responsible for the pollution.

children.name: undoubted
children.definition: adjective
examples: used to emphasize that something is true
_She is the undoubted star of British ballet.

children.name: certainty
children.definition: 1 the state of being completely certain
examples: with certainty
She knew with absolute certainty that he’d say no.
The result is impossible to predict with anydegree of certainty.
2[U] the fact that something is certain to happen
certainty of (doing) something
the certainty of being caught
certainty that
There’s no certainty that he’ll remember.
